Benefit: Assembles all data for all species in one place in a common format
Example: Assists rapid prototyping of operating models and proposing candidate data-based management procedures
Provides a quick reference when initiating or reviewing any stock assessment

Benefit: Many visualizations in a tight space encourages comparison across data sets
Example: All fisheries dependent and independent index trends can be compared for similarities and contrasts
Spatial and temporal trends can be considered simultaneously

Benefit: Promotes regular review of survey trends for all species
Example: Noticing recent declines in multiple survey indices for a stock with no planned assessment
Can assist discussions of stock assessment prioritization

Benefit: Builds trust between contributors of data and government agency
Example: Industry associations that have contributed time or money to survey programs can see their data being used
Data collected with tax-payer funds are not left hidden on internal government servers

Benefit: Makes data interpretable to all interested parties
Example: Unlike internal tools, makes visualized data available to public, Indigenous people, NGOs, fishing industry, fishery managers, consultants
Open data is not enough---many interested parties lack the skills, time, and institutional knowledge to turn raw data into interpretable graphics
Ensures data have been interpreted appropriately and with caveats by those with institutional knowledge

Benefit: Highlights data richness and data poverty
Example: Assists with discussions of survey data prioritization, e.g., aging-structure collection priorities
Detecting consistent deviations in survey indices across stocks indicating historical deviations from survey design
Detecting fish lengths entered in wrong units

Benefit: Data extraction process has been peer-reviewed
Example: Allows for rapid data extraction and sharing with collaborators
